keywords.term: HZI, Helmholtz Centre for Infection Research

p.s: The Journal of Immunology IkB NS Regulates Murine Th17 Differentiation during Gut Inflammation and Infection Michaela Annemann,* , † Zuobai Wang, ‡ Carlos Plaza-Sirvent,* , † Rainer Glauben, x Marc Schuster,* , † Frida Ewald Sander,* , † Panagiota Mamareli, ‡ Anja A. K€ uhl, x Britta Siegmund, x Matthias Lochner, ‡ and Ingo Schmitz* , † IL-17-producing Th17 cells mediate immune responses against a variety of fungal and bacterial infections.
Signaling via NF-kB has been linked to the development and maintenance of Th17 cells.
We analyzed the role of the unusual inhibitor of NF-kB, IkB NS , in the proliferation and effector cytokine production of murine Th17 cells.
Our study demonstrates that nuclear IkB NS is crucial for murine Th17 cell generation.
IkB NS is highly expressed in Th17 cells; in the absence of IkB NS , the frequencies of IL-17Aproducing cells are drastically reduced.
This was measured in vitro under Th17-polarizing conditions and confirmed in two colitis models.
Mechanistically, murine IkB NS 2/2 Th17 cells were less proliferative and expressed markedly reduced levels of IL-2, IL-10, MIP-1a, and GM-CSF.
Citrobacter rodentium was used as a Th17-inducing infection model, in which IkB NS 2/2 mice displayed an increased bacterial burden and diminished tissue damage.
These results demonstrate the important function of Th17 cells in pathogen clearance, as well as in inflammation-associated pathology.
We identified IkB NS to be crucial for the generation and function of murine Th17 cells upon inflammation and infection.
Our findings may have implications for the therapy of autoimmune conditions, such as inflammatory bowel disease, and for the treatment of gut-tropic infections.
The Journal of Immunology, 2015, 194: 2888-2898.
T he identification of the proinflammatory Th17 cell subset marked a significant breakthrough in our understanding of the Th cell compartment (1, 2), expanding the established Th1/Th2 paradigm (3).
Previously, only the regulation of cellular immune responses against viruses by Th1 cells and humoral responses by Th2 cells in response to extracellular pathogens were known (3).
Today, we know that Th17 cells are essential for host protection against a variety of extracellular bacteria and fungi located predominantly in the gastrointestinal tract, skin, and lungs.
Consequently, most Th17 cells are found in these mucosal tissues upon infection; however, some reside in the lamina propria (LP) under steady-state conditions (4,5).

Th17 cells depend on the transcription factor RORgt (6) and primarily produce the cytokine IL-17A, which is a potent inducer of other proinflammatory cytokines, such as IL-6, IL-1b, and TNF-a, in a variety of IL-17R-expressing cell types, including endothelial cells, epithelial cells, and macrophages (7,8).
IL-17A is also involved in the recruitment and activation of neutrophils to sites of infection (7).
Moreover, Th17 cells secrete GM-CSF, which controls granulocyte and macrophage maturation.
Expression of GM-CSF was reported to be responsible for the pathogenicity of Th17 cells during experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) (9,10), the murine disease model for multiple sclerosis.
Of note, IL-17-producing T cells can be generated in vitro by treating naive CD4 + cells with TGF-b and IL-6 (11,12) because both cytokines induce the expression of RORgt (6).
NF-kB is an inducible transcription factor and is crucial for lymphocyte development and function (13).
In T cells, activation of NF-kB signaling is governed by the CARMA1, MALT1, and BCL10 complex that activates the inhibitor of kB kinase (IKK) complex (14).
The IKK complex phosphorylates IkBa, which binds to NF-kB transcription factors and causes cytoplasmic retention of NF-kB by blocking the nuclear-localization signal (15).
After phosphorylation by IKKb, IkBa becomes polyubiquitinated and, finally, undergoes proteasomal degradation (13).
Consequently, NF-kB is released, enters the nucleus, and regulates gene expression via binding to kB sites.
NF-kB transcription factors are dimers composed of two members of the Rel-protein family, comprising p50, p52, p65/RelA, c-Rel, and RelB (13).
In the nucleus, these transcription factors are regulated via atypical IkB proteins, which include IkB NS (encoded by the gene Nfkbid), IkBz, BCL-3, and IkBh (16).
We reported recently that the atypical NF-kB inhibitor IkB NS regulates regulatory T cell (Treg) generation (17).
Although IkB NS 2/2 mice display a severe reduction in Treg numbers, they do not develop signs of spontaneous autoimmunity (17).
Thus, we speculated that IkB NS might be important for the activation, proliferation, or cytokine production of proinflammatory effector T cells.
Indeed, we observed strong expression of IkB NS in CD4 + cells and strongly impaired Th17 responses in vitro and in vivo.
Our results demonstrate that IkB NS is required for Th17 differentiation and function.
B6.129/SV-NFKBID(tm1Clay) mice, later referred to as IkB NS 2/2 mice, were described previously (18).
IkB NS 2/2 mice were crossed to Foxp3DTR-eGFP mice, as previously described, later referred as IkB NS 2/2 Foxp3 DTR-eGFP reporter mice (17).

IkB NS 2/2 , IkB NS 2/2 Foxp3 DTR-eGFP , and B6.PL-Thy1 a / CyJ mice (Thy1.1 mice) were bred under specific pathogen-free conditions in the animal facility of the Helmholtz Centre for Infection Research.
B6.129S7-Rag1 tm1Mom (RAG1 2/2 ) mice (19) were bred at the animal facility of the Charite ´-Universita ¨tsmedizin Berlin.
All animal experiments and breeding were performed in accordance with the guidelines of national and local authorities.

To induce colitis, mice were fed in four cycles, each comprising 7 d, with drinking water containing 3% (w/v) dextran sodium sulfate (DSS) as an initial dose and 2% (w/v) DSS for all further treatments, followed by 14 d of feeding with DSS-free water.
Inflammation of the colon was assessed at the end of the last cycle.
Body weight was measured during the progression of colitis.
Consistency of the stool and rectal bleeding were scored as described previously (17).
At the end of the experiment, the length of the colon was measured from the cecum to the anus.
To analyze histological changes in the colon, colon samples were fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde, embedded in paraffin, and cut into 2-mm sections.
The colon sections were deparaffinized and stained with H&E.
Fixed colon samples were scored in a blinded manner, as described earlier (17).
The histological score of DSS colitis is the sum of the individual scores for inflammatory cell infiltrations and tissue damage.

For adoptive-transfer colitis, spleen and lymph nodes were used to isolate CD4 + CD25 2 T cells from wild-type or IkB NS 2/2 mice or CD4 + GFP + Tregs from wild-type or IkB NS 2/2 Foxp3 DTR-eGFP reporter mice.

The cells were sorted via flow cytometry (FACSAria II; BD Biosciences) or by using MACS separation kits (CD4 T Cell Isolation Kit, CD25-PE Kit; Miltenyi Biotec), as described in the supplier's manual.
A total of 200 ml 13 PBS containing 5 3 10 5 CD4 + CD25 2 T cells, alone or together with 5 3 10 5 CD4 + GFP + Tregs, were injected i.p. into RAG1 2/2 mice.
Body weight was monitored during colitis progression.
Consistency of the stool and rectal bleeding were scored as described earlier (17).
The length of the colon was measured from the cecum to the anus, and colon samples were scored in a blinded manner, as described previously (17).
Mice were infected with C. rodentium strain ICC180 expressing the luxoperon (courtesy of S. Wiles, Auckland, New Zealand).
C. rodentium were cultured in Lennox broth medium (Roth) at 37˚C overnight.
The next day, the bacteria were adjusted to 1 3 10 11 CFU in 1 ml 13 PBS.
A total of 1 3 10 10 C. rodentium was administered to mice orally.
Body weight was monitored during the progression of infection.
Bacteria-derived bioluminescence during infection was measured in vivo by bioluminescence imaging using IVIS Spectrum CT.
At day 10, the length of the colon was measured from the cecum to the anus.
The stool was collected in 1 ml Lennox broth, weighed, homogenized, and diluted serially.
To determine the bacterial load in organs, the liver and spleen were homogenized and diluted serially.
Serial dilutions were added to MacConkey Agar (Roth) and cultured at 37˚C for 24 h.
CFU were counted and, for feces, bacterial burden was normalized to stool weight.

For histology of C. rodentiuminfected mice, whole-colon samples were placed in a shape of a "Swiss roll" and fixed in 4% Roti-Histofix (Roth), embedded in paraffin, cut into 8-mm sections, deparaffinized, stained with H&E, and scored in a blinded manner.
The histological sections were scored for epithelial hyperplasia (score based on percentage above the height of the control where 0 = no change, 1 = 1-50%, 2 = 51-100%, and 3 = .

Epithelial integrity was scored as follows: 0, no change; 1, mild epithelial ulceration and cryptic destruction; 2, moderate epithelial ulceration and cryptic destruction; and 3, severe epithelial ulceration and cryptic destruction.
Tissue sections were scored for mononuclear cell infiltration as follows: 0, no change; 1, mild; 2, moderate; and 3, severe.
To isolate cells from LP, colons were placed into 15 ml ice-chilled 0.5 mM EDTA for 30 min (on ice), followed by sufficient rinsing with 13 PBS to remove residual epithelium.
Then the tissue was cut into fine pieces and digested in DMEM (Life Technologies) supplemented with 1 mg/ml Collagenase D (Roche) and 0.1 mg/ml DNase I (Roche) three times for 30 min at 37˚C.
After each round of incubation, cells were suspended by passing them through a 100-mm mesh.
After centrifugation, the cell pellet was resuspended in a 40% isotonic Percoll solution (GE Healthcare) and underlain with an 80% isotonic Percoll solution.
After centrifugation (900 3 g, room temperature for 20 min), LP lymphocytes (LPLs) were yielded from the interface cell ring of the 40-80% Percoll gradient.
Cells were washed with PBS containing 2% FCS and used for further studies.

In vitro generation of Th cell subsets CD4 + CD62L high CD25 2 naive T cells were sorted via flow cytometry (FACSAria II; BD Biosciences or MoFlo; Beckman and Coulter) and resuspended in primary T cell medium (IMDM containing 10% FCS, 50 mg/ml penicillin/streptomycin, 25 mM HEPES, 0.05 mM 2-ME, 1% nonessential amino acids, 1 mM sodium pyruvate).

Two 3 10 5 cells were seeded per well (96-well plate) and were activated with plate-bound anti-CD3 and anti-CD28 (both from BioLegend) in the presence of priming cytokines and inhibitory Abs, according to the respective Th subset: Th0-2 mg/ml anti-CD3 (145-2C11; BioLegend), 2 mg/ml anti-CD28 (37.51;
BioLegend), 10 mg/ml anti-IL-4 (11B11; made in-house), and 10 mg/ml anti-IFN-g (XMG1.2;
made in-house); Th1-2 mg/ml anti-CD3 (145-2C11; BioLegend), 2 mg/ml anti-CD28 (37.51;
BioLegend), 10 mg/ml anti-IL-4 (11B11; made in-house), and 10 ng/ml IL-12 (R&D Systems); and Th17-3 mg/ml anti-CD3 (145-2C11; BioLegend), 5 mg/ml anti-CD28 (37.51;
BioLegend), 10 mg/ml anti-IL-2 (JES6-1A12; Bio-Legend), 10 mg/ml anti-IFN-g (XMG1.2;
made in-house), 2 ng/ml porcine TGF-b (R&D Systems), 30 ng/ml IL-6 (R&D Systems), 10 ng/ml IL-1b (R&D Systems), and 20 ng/ml TNF-a (PeproTech).
Cells were analyzed on day 4.

div.head: In vitro expansion of CD4 + CD25 2 T cells

p.s: After sorting of CD4 + CD25 2 T cells, 4 3 10 6 cells were expanded in RPMI 1640 supplemented with 10% FCS, 1 mM sodium pyruvate, 13 nonessential amino acids, 50 ng/ml penicillin/streptomycin, and 50 mM 2-ME.
For expansion, cells were stimulated in a six-well plate with 1 mg/ml plate-bound anti-CD3 and 2 mg/ml soluble anti-CD28 in the presence of 10 ng/ml murine IL-2.
On day 3, cells were transferred into a 10-cm dish in a total volume of 15 ml fresh RPMI 1640 with supplements.
On day 6, 5 3 10 6 to 10 3 10 6 cells were seeded on a 12-well plate and centrifuged for 2 min at 800 rpm at room temperature.
Cells were stimulated with coated anti-CD3 (10 mg/ml) plus anti-CD28 (5 mg/ml) for 15 or 30 min or for 1, 2, or 4 h; stimulated with PMA (10 ng/ml) plus ionomycin (1 mM) for 2 h; or left untreated.
Subsequently, cells were analyzed by Western blotting.
For proliferation analysis, sorted naive T cells were stained with CFSE (eBioscience).
Briefly, T cells were washed two times with 13 PBS and resuspended in 13 PBS to a concentration of 2 3 10 6 /ml.
CFSE was added to a final concentration of 5 mM.
Cells were incubated for 10 min (CFSE) at 37˚C in the dark and cultured under Th0-, Th1-, or Th17-polarizing conditions.
On day 4, cells were stained for surface markers and intracellular proteins and analyzed by flow cytometry.

div.head: Enrichment of Th17 cells via mouse IL-17 Secretion Assay

p.s: Naive T cells were isolated and cultured under Th17-polarizing conditions, as described above.
On day 4, cells were stimulated with PMA (10 ng/ml) and ionomycin (1 mM; both from Sigma-Aldrich) for 3 h at 37˚C.
A mouse IL-17 Secretion Assay (Miltenyi Biotec) was used for enrichment of IL-17 + cells.
The cells were incubated and enriched according to the supplier's instruction manual, and isolated cells were used to analyze cytokine secretion.
To analyze the cytokine secretion of enriched IL-17-secreting cells by Proteome Profiler Array, 0.8 3 10 6 cells were stimulated with PMA (10 ng/ml) and ionomycin (1 mM; both from Sigma-Aldrich).
After 4 h, the supernatant was taken and used undiluted or diluted 1:10 or 1:50 for cytokine analysis using the Proteome Profiler Array (R&D Systems).
The array membrane was activated and thereafter incubated with the Th17 supernatant, as described in
The Journal of Immunology the user manual.
Finally, the chemiluminescence of the membrane was measured using the Fusion FX-7 camera (Vilber Lourmat), and the volume of bands was quantified with the program BIO-1D (Peqlab).
To analyze the cytokine secretion of Th17 cells by flow cytometry, 0.8 3 10 6 enriched IL-17-secreting cells were stimulated with PMA (10 ng/ml) and ionomycin (1 mM; both from Sigma-Aldrich).
After 4 h, the supernatant was used for cytokine analysis with a FlowCytomix kit (eBioscience).
The supernatant was used undiluted or was diluted 1:10 or 1:50.

The standard curves and samples were prepared according to the manufacturer's instructions and measured by flow cytometry in the BD LSR II Flow Cytometer System or the BD LSRFortessa (BD Biosciences).
For intracellular cytokine staining, cells were stimulated for 4 h with PMA (10 ng/ml) and ionomycin (1 mM; both from Sigma-Aldrich).
Brefeldin A (10 mg/ml; Sigma-Aldrich) was added during the last 2 h of stimulation.
Live/dead staining was performed in 100 ml 13 PBS (Invitrogen) containing one of the LIVE/DEAD dyes from Life Technologies (30 min, 4˚C, in the dark).

Surface markers were incubated in FACS buffer (13 PBS, 2% w/v BSA, 0.01% v/v NaN 3 ) at 4˚C, for 15 to 20 min in the dark, using the following fluorochrome-conjugated Abs: CD3-allophycocyanin-eFluor 780 (17A2; eBioscience), CD3-FITC (145-2C11; BD), CD3-PECy7 (145-2C11; eBioscience), CD4-Alexa Fluor 488 (RM4-5; BD), CD4-allophycocyanin (RM4-5; eBioscience), CD4-FITC (RM4-5; eBioscience), CD4-Pacific Blue (RM4-5; BioLegend), CD4-PE (RM4-5; BD), CD4-PerCP-Cy5.5 (RM4-5; eBioscience), CD8-allophycocyanin (53-6.7;
BD), CD8-FITC (53-6.7;
BD), CD25-allophycocyanin (PC61; BD), and CD62L-PerCPCy5.5 (MEL-14; eBioscience).
Subsequently, the cells were fixed and permeabilized using the FoxP3 Staining Buffer Set (Miltenyi Biotec) for 30 min (4˚C, in the dark).
Intracellular cytokine staining was performed in 100 ml 13 permeabilization buffer using IFN-g-FITC (XMG1.2),
IFN-g-PE (XMG1.2),
IFN-g-PECy7 (XMG1.2),
and IL-17A-allophycocyanin (eBio17B7; all from eBioscience) Abs (4˚C, for 30 min in the dark).
Labeled cells were analyzed with a BD LSR II Flow Cytometer System or BD LSRFortessa (BD Biosciences).

For flow cytometric analysis upon C. rodentium infection, cells from the spleen and mesenteric lymph nodes, as well as LPLs, were restimulated for 6 h in medium containing IL-23 (20 ng/ml) with PMA (10 ng/ml) and ionomycin (1 mg/ml; both from Sigma-Aldrich).
Brefeldin A (10 mg/ml; Sigma-Aldrich) was added for the last 3 h.

Cells were processed for flow cytometry, as described above, and an Fc-block step (10 min, on ice) was included before cell surface staining and the fixation/permeabilization buffers (eBioscience) were used.

div.head: Cell lysis and determination of protein concentration

p.s: Total-cell lysates were obtained by lysing in TPNE lysis buffer (13 PBS, 300 mM NaCl, 2 mM EDTA, 1% v/v Triton X-100) supplemented with 1 mM PMSF, 1 mg/ml protease inhibitor mix (aprotinin, leupeptin, Pepstatin A, chymostatin), and 0.4 mM sodium orthovanadate.
Incubation for 20 min on ice was followed by centrifugation (14,000 rpm, 4˚C, 15 min).
The protein concentration of the lysate was determined by a BCA Protein Assay (Thermo Scientific), following the manufacturer's instructions.
For protein separation via SDS-PAGE, 20-40 mg the protein lysate was loaded onto a gel.
Proteins were separated on a 12% polyacrylamide gel.
For further analysis, the proteins were blotted onto a polyvinylidene difluoride membrane (GE Healthcare) and detected with the following Abs: b-actin
For chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) analyses, Th17 cells were generated and stimulated with PMA/ionomycin for 4 h, as described above.
ChIP was performed with a ChIP-IT Express Enzymatic kit (Active Motif), using a modified procedure to achieve ChIP without cross-linking.
Hence, procedural steps to remove paraformaldehyde and to reverse cross-linking were not performed.
Rabbit polyclonal IkB NS Ab was used; after elution of the precipitated DNA, IL-10 was amplified by real-time PCR.
cDNA was used as a template for real-time PCR using SYBR Green (Roche).
Ubiquitin C (UBC) was used as a housekeeping gene for normalization.

Measurements were run in duplicates in the LightCycler 480 system using the following primers: GM-CSF forward (fwd), 59-GCATG-TAGAGGCCATCAAAGA-39 and GM-CSF reverse (rev), 59-CGGGTCTG-CACACATGTTA-39; IFN-g fwd, 59-ATCTGGAGGAACTGGCAAAA-39 and IFN-g rev, 59-TTCAAGACTTCAAAGAGTCTGAGGTA-39; IkB NS fwd, 59-GGGCTCTTTTCCCATTCTCT-39 and IkB NS rev, 59-GGACACAATCC-AGCCTGTCT-39; IL-2 fwd, 59-CCTGAGCAGGATGGAGAATTACA-39 and IL-2 rev, 59-TCCAGAACATGCCGCAGAG-39; IL-10 fwd, 59-TGCC-AAGCCTTATCGGAAATG-39 and IL-10 rev, 59-CCCAGGGAATTCAAA-TGCTCC-39; IL-17a fwd, 59-CAGGGAGAGCTTCATCTGTGT-39 and IL-17a rev, 59-GCTGAGCTTTGAGGGATGAT-39; IL-17f fwd, 59-CAAAAC-CAGGGCATTTCTGT-39 and IL-17f rev, 59-ATGGTGCTGTCTTCCTGA-CC-39; IL-22 fwd, 59-TCATCGGGGAGAAACTGTTC-39 and IL-22 rev, 59-CATGTAGGGCTGGAACCTGT-39; MIP-1a fwd, 59-ATGAAGGTCTCCA-CCACTG-39 and MIP-1a rev, 59-GCATTCAGTTCCAGGTCA-39; RORgt fwd, 59-TGCAAGACTCATCGACAAGG-39 and ROR gt rev, 59-AGGGGA-TTCAACATCAGTGC-39; and UBC fwd, 59-AAGAGAATCCACAAGG-AATTGAATG-39 and UBC rev, 59-CAACAGGACCTGCTGAACACTG-39.
GraphPad Prism software (GraphPad) was used for all statistical analyses.
To determine statistical significance, the two-tailed Mann-Whitney U test or Student t test was used; error bars represent the SEM.

div.head: IkB NS triggers Th17 development during gut inflammation

p.s: In response to intestinal infections and inflammation, Th17 cells accumulate in the gut and surrounding lymphoid tissues (20,21).

To unveil whether IkB NS deficiency affects Th cell differentiation, we induced chronic colitis that is promoted by Th1 and Th17, as well as B cells (22), in IkB NS 2/2 and wild-type mice by repeated DSS feeding.

Although DSS-fed IkB NS 2/2 and wild-type mice did not display marked histological differences, there was inherent colon damage in the nontreated IkB NS 2/2 mice that was not present in wild-type mice (Supplemental Fig. 1A-D).
Most importantly, the frequency of IL-17A + T cells was decreased in LPLs of IkB NS 2/2 mice compared with wild-type mice (Supplemental Fig. 1E, 1F).
Interestingly, Th17 frequencies already were reduced in nontreated, IkB NS 2/2 animals compared with respective wildtype mice (Supplemental Fig. 1E, 1F).
Next, we investigated whether Th17 differentiation also is impaired in T cell-based transfer colitis.
Rag1 2/2 mice receiving IkB NS 2/2 T cells exhibited significantly more colon damage than did wild-type controls (Fig. 1A).
Importantly, the induction of both IL-17A + IFN-g 2 (Fig. 1B, 1C) and IL-17A + IFN-g + (Fig. 1D) T cells was completely blunted in IkB NS 2/2 mice.
In contrast, the frequency of IL-17A 2 IFN-g + T cells (Fig. 1E) was slightly, but significantly, increased in IkB NS Foxp3 DTR-eGFP reporter mice were cotransferred (Fig. 1F).
The cotransfer of Tregs had no effect on the increased Th1 cell frequency in IkB NS 2/2 mice, regardless of whether the Tregs were IkB NS deficient or proficient.
In summary, both colitis models revealed a requirement for IkB NS in Th17 cell differentiation during gut inflammation.

div.head: IkB NS drives Th17 and Th1 development in vitro

p.s: To determine whether IkB NS is differentially expressed in Th cell subsets, we analyzed IkB NS (Nfkbid) expression at the mRNA level by real-time PCR (Fig. 2).
We detected comparable Nfkbid mRNA expression in unprimed T cells (Th0) and in Th1-and Th17-polarized cells upon restimulation with PMA and ionomycin (Fig. 2A).
In addition, high IkB NS expression was observed at the protein level in reactivated T cells (Fig. 2B).
Similar findings were obtained when T cells were restimulated with anti-CD3 and anti-CD28 Abs (Fig. 2C, 2D).
Th1 cells exhibited a higher IkB NS protein expression than did Th17 cells.

Notably, the nonactivated Th17 cells displayed higher IkB NS expression compared with the other nonactivated cells (Fig. 2B, 2D), substantiating a pivotal role for IkB NS specifically in this T cell subset.
Indeed, during in vitro priming we monitored severely reduced frequencies of both IL-17A + Th17 cells and IFN-g + Th1 cells in the absence of IkB NS (Fig. 2E, 2F).
We conclude that IkB NS expression is not restricted to a single Th cell subset but forces the differentiation of Th17 and Th1 cells in vitro.

div.head: Proliferation defect in IkB NS -deficient Th17 cells

p.s: To identify the reason for the reduced frequency of Th17 and Th1 cells induced by IkB NS deficiency, we first analyzed Th cell proliferation in vitro.

Although all T cells proliferated equally during the first 2 d of culture, IkB NS 2/2 T cells primed for both Th17 and Th1 differentiation proliferated much less compared with the wild-type cells in the following days (Supplemental Fig. 2).
To determine whether wild-type cells could compensate for the proliferation defect of IkB NS 2/2 cells when cocultured, we dif- ferentiated IkB NS 2/2 (CD90.2
+ ) T cells in the presence of congenic wild-type (CD90.1 + ) cells, both stained with CFSE.
Again, the frequencies of IkB NS 2/2 Th0, Th1, and Th17 cells showed a 50% reduction compared with wild-type cells, suggesting a cellintrinsic effect of IkB NS on T cell differentiation (Fig. 3A).
The CFSE profile and mean number of divisions/cell (division index) revealed enhanced proliferation of wild-type Th0, Th1, and Th17 cells compared with IkB NS 2/2 cells (Fig. 3B, 3C).
Remarkably, the proliferation defect caused by IkB NS deficiency was most pronounced in Th17-differentiated cells.

Of note, the proliferation defect was not due to impaired proximal TCR signaling because tyrosine phosphorylation; the activation of the kinases Akt, ERK, and p38; expression of the NF-kB family members c-Rel, NF-kB1, NF-kB2, p65, and RelB; and the expression and phosphorylation status of IkBa were unaltered (Supplemental Fig. 3).

div.head: IkB NS regulates Th17 cytokine expression

p.s: Because RORgt is an essential transcription factor for Th17 differentiation and function ( 6), we analyzed the expression of Rorc (encoding RORgt) in IkB NS 2/2 and wild-type Th1 and Th17 cells by real-time PCR.
Despite defective Th17 differentiation of IkB NS 2/2 cells, Rorc expression was comparable in wild-type and IkB NS 2/2 Th17 cells (Fig. 4A).
Next, we analyzed whether IkB NS 2/2 Th17 cells display an altered cytokine expression profile.

Coculturing wild-type and IkB NS 2/2 T cells under Th17polarizing conditions, we observed, in addition to the proliferation defect (Fig. 3), a significantly decreased mean fluorescence intensity (MFI) of IL-17A in IkB NS 2/2 cells (Fig. 4B, 4C), indicating a role for IkB NS in Th17 cell function.
To determine whether IkB NS also impairs the expression of other cytokines, a cytokine array membrane was performed.
We enriched in vitrogenerated wild-type and IkB NS 2/2 Th17 cells to obtain comparable numbers of IL-17A-secreting cells.
The results revealed reduced secretion of IL-2, IL-10, GM-CSF (Csf2), and MIP-1a (Ccl3) by IkB NS 2/2 Th17 cells (Fig. 4D, Supplemental Fig. 4).
Using a bead-based assay and flow cytometry, the reduced secretion of the cytokines IL-2, IL-10, and MIP-1a in IkB NS
Th17 cells was verified (Fig. 4E).
Nevertheless, secretion of the The Journal of Immunology Th17 cytokines IL-17A, IL-17F, and IL-22 was not affected by IkB NS deficiency.
Furthermore, we analyzed the effect of IkB NS on mRNA expression of the respective cytokines in stimulated Th17 cells by real-time PCR.
In accordance with the protein data, we detected reduced mRNA expression of Il10 and Csf2 in IkB NS 2/2 Th17 cells, whereas Il17a and Il17f expression was not affected (Fig. 4F).
Interestingly, in contrast to IL-22 cytokine secretion, IkB NS 2/2 Th17 cells showed an increased expression of IL-22 mRNA.
We conclude that IkB NS regulates the expression of multiple key Th17 cytokines.

IkB NS 2/2 mice display impaired Th17 development and high susceptibility to C. rodentium infection C. rodentium is a noninvasive pathogen that establishes acute infections in the murine large intestine (23).
The adaptive immune response plays an important role for the host response to C. rodentium because mice lacking B and T cells are unable to clear the infection (24).
C. rodentium induces a strong Th17 response (25,26).
Therefore, we examined whether IkB NS is required for an appropriate host response against C. rodentium.
The bacterial burden in feces of IkB NS 2/2 mice at day 10 postinfection was significantly increased compared with wild-type mice (Fig. 5A).
A closer investigation of colonization using live in vivo imaging indicated a similar infection kinetic in mice of both genotypes until day 5 (Fig. 5B, 5C).

However, although the bioluminescent signal from the gut of wild-type mice started to decrease between days 7 and 10, the signal intensity increased in IkB NS 2/2 mice, confirming impaired C. rodentium clearance in these animals (Fig. 5B, 5C).

In line with this observation, IkB NS 2/2 mice also suffered from an elevated systemic infection, because dissemination of the pathogen to the liver was significantly enhanced in IkB NS 2/2 mice compared with wild-type mice (Fig. 5D).
These findings indicate that IkB NS is required for restricting C. rodentium infections to the gut.
We next studied the impact of IkB NS deficiency on the host T cell response.
We found that the frequencies of Th17 cells were reduced by ∼50% in the colonic LP and in the spleen (Fig. 6A, 6B).

Interestingly, the frequency of IL-17A + IFN-g + doublepositive cells showed a similar reduction in both organs (Fig. 6A, 6C), whereas the frequency of IFN-g + Th1 cells was slightly reduced in the spleen of IkB NS 2/2 mice but not in the other organs investigated (Fig. 6A, 6D).
In addition, we examined LP cellderived mRNA levels of the cytokines IFN-g, IL-10, IL-17A, IL-17F, and IL-22 by real-time PCR.
Consistent with the previous data, IkB NS deficiency resulted in decreased mRNA expression of Ifng, Il17a, Il17f, and Il10 by LPLs of the colon (Fig. 6E).
In contrast with the in vitro data, but consistent with the other cytokines in vivo, the expression of Il22 mRNA was slightly downregulated in IkB NS 2/2 mice (Fig. 6E).
To assess whether IkB NS deficiency also affects pathology of the colon, we investigated cellular infiltration and the level of tissue damage in the colon of infected mice.

Despite the increased bacterial burden, IkB NS 2/2 mice exhibited significantly less immunopathology in the large intestine compared with wild-type mice (Fig. 6F), suggesting that the defective Th17 immune response in these mice results in less inflammation-induced tissue destruction.
Altogether, our data demonstrate that IkB NS promotes Th17 differentiation and cytokine expression to fight intestinal infections.

div.head: IkB NS binds to the Il10 gene locus

p.s: The expression of several cytokines is regulated by the proteins of the IkB family (16).
For instance, it was described that IkBz and IkB NS regulate the expression of IL-6 by binding to its promoter (27,28).
In this study, we consistently found that expression of IL-10 is affected by IkB NS deficiency in various in vitro and in vivo experiments.
To investigate whether IkB NS regulates the expression of IL-10 directly by binding to its gene locus, we performed native ChIP experiments.
We detected increased binding of IkB NS to the Il10 gene locus in stimulated Th17 cells compared with unstimulated Th17 cells and IkB NS -deficient controls (Fig. 7).
This suggests that IL-10 is a direct IkB NS target gene and that IkB NS regulates Th17 differentiation, at least in part, by direct control of cytokine expression.
We recently reported that IkB NS regulates the induction of Foxp3 expression in Tregs (17).
Although IkB NS 2/2 mice displayed a severe reduction in immunosuppressive Tregs, we found no signs of autoimmune disease.
Thus, we speculated that IkB NS promotes the development or function of proinflammatory T cells.
In this study, we show that IkB NS additionally controls the proliferation and cytokine expression of differentiated CD4 + effector T cells.

Although impaired in vitro proliferation of IkB NS 2/2 thymic and peripheral CD4 + and CD8 + cells upon anti-CD3 and anti-CD28 stimulation was reported (18), our data indicate that Th17 cells are particularly affected by IkB NS deficiency.

We fur-ther unveiled that the proliferation defect of IkB NS 2/2 T cells primed for Th17 differentiation could not be overcome by the presence of wild-type cells, indicating that IkB NS 's function is T cell intrinsic.
Remarkably, we also detected expression of IkB NS in acutely stimulated Th1 and Th0 cells.
Overall, IkB NS expression in Th1 and Th0 cells was comparable to the expression measured in Th17 cells.
Differences between mRNA and protein expression might be due to posttranscriptional control of IkB NS expression by Roquin, which was described previously in cell lines (29).
Of note, fewer Th1 cells were generated in vitro from IkB NS 2/2 naive cells as a result of impaired proliferation.
Importantly, IkB NS does not affect proximal TCR signaling.
Thus, IkB NS forces proliferation further downstream in the signaling cascade.
Noteworthy, in vivo proliferation of IkB NS 2/2 Tregs is not altered (17).
Therefore, IkB NS acts differentially in Tregs and effector T cells.
For instance, IkB NS is required for development but not function of Tregs (17), whereas in differentiated CD4 + Th cells, it regulates proliferation and effector cytokine production.
Thus, our findings We (17) and other investigators (30) previously described severe pathological changes in the colon in IkB NS 2/2 mice as a result of DSS-induced and transfer colitis, respectively.
In the current study, chronic DSS colitis led to a reduced number of IL-17A + Th17 cells in IkB NS 2/2 mice compared with wild-type mice.
Furthermore, using a T cell-dependent transfer colitis model, we demonstrated that almost no Th17 cells or IL-17A + IFN-g + T cells developed from transferred IkB NS 2/2 T cells.
Hence, IkB NS is not only an important regulator of Th17 priming in vitro, it is also essential for Th17 and IL-17A + IFN-g + T cell development in mouse models of gut inflammation.
Furthermore, tissue damage in the gut was increased in recipients of IkB NS 2/2 T cells as a result of the reduced numbers of immunosuppressive Tregs, as previously reported (17).
In addition to a lower Treg frequency, the elevated frequency of IFN-g + Th1 cells is likely to be responsible for the enhanced pathological damage.
Although both IkB NS In addition to the autoimmune models of colitis, we addressed the question of whether IkB NS is instrumental for Th17 responses during infection.
To this end, we used C. rodentium because this murine pathogen induces strong Th17 responses (25,26,31).

C. rodentium shares virulence factors with enteropathogenic Escherichia coli and enterohemorrhagic E. coli and, thus, is a commonly used murine model to study immune responses against these guttropic pathogens (32).
Similar to the colitis models, IkB NS deficiency resulted in impaired Th17 and IL-17A + IFN-g + T cell generation in infected mice.

Because IFN-g, as well as the p40 and the p19 subunit of IL-23, which is known to stabilize the Th17 phenotype (33), are required for C. rodentium clearance (25,34,35), it is conceivable that the lack of IL-17A + and IFN-g + T cells in IkB NS 2/2 mice upon C. rodentium infection is responsible for the increased bacterial burden in these mice.

Interestingly, NF-kB1/ p50 2/2 mice also are defective in C. rodentium clearance (36), which is in line with the observation that IkB NS preferentially interacts with this NF-kB family member (17,37).
Furthermore, because of the normal IL-17A and IL-17F expression in vitro, we speculate that the reduced mRNA expression in vivo arises from the decreased frequency of Th17 and IL-17A + IFN-g + cells.
In addition to IL-17A and IL-17F, which were involved in late host defense against C. rodentium, the IL-10 cytokine family member IL-22 is essential in early host protection (26,38).
IL-22 2/2 mice exhibit increased damage to the intestinal epithelium, systemic bacterial burden, and mortality (39).
In this study, we observed an increased mRNA, but unaltered protein, expression of IL-22 by IkB NS 2/2 cells in vitro.
Of note, Il22 expression was reduced in vivo upon C. rodentium infection.

The reduced IL-22 levels might be sufficient to support protection of the intestinal epithelium; however, the defects in the expression of IL-22 and other cytokines were insufficient to reduce bacterial burden.
Why do we see decreased histological damage in C. rodentiuminfected IkB NS 2/2 mice despite the increase in bacterial burden?
Interestingly, IL-23 also was reported to induce GM-CSF expression in Th17 cells, which causes pathogenicity in EAE, the murine model for multiple sclerosis (9, 10).
Thus, the reduction in GM-CSF production by IkB NS 2/2 Th17 cells may account for the reduced tissue damage in the gut.
Alternatively, impaired bacterial clearance in conjunction with reduced tissue damage was reported recently (40).
In this infection model, Th17 differentiation depended on the presence of Tregs and the consumption of IL-2.
Thus, it appears that Th17 cells during C. rodentium infection are not only involved in pathogen clearance (i.e., beneficial), they also cause tissue damage and, therefore, can be pathogenic.
In addition to proinflammatory or pathogenic Th17 cells, protective or suppressive Th17 cells have been described (21,41).
For instance, IL-10-expressing Th17 cells that were primed with TGF-b and IL-6 were not pathogenic (41).
Therefore, IL-10 coexpression by Th17 cells is presumably a self-regulatory mechanism to reduce the inflammatory damage of Th17 cells.

Although it was initially believed that Th17 cells produce IL-10 early on in an infection (41), it was later shown that Th17 cells migrate from the spleen to the gut in a CCR6-dependent manner and acquire suppressive function and IL-10 expression there (21).
We found decreased IL-10 expression in IkB NS 2/2 Th17 cells both when generated in vitro and in mice infected with C. rodentium.
Therefore, IkB NS is crucial for the differentiation of proinflammatory, as well as suppressive, Th17 cells.
We showed previously that IkB NS in Tregs is essential to induce the expression of the transcription factor Foxp3 (17).
IkB NS binds together with p50 and c-Rel to CNS3 and the promoter of Foxp3.
Because of the extenuated expression of IL-10 in vivo and in vitro, we analyzed the influence of IkB NS in IL-10 expression by ChIP, which revealed binding of IkB NS to the IL-10 gene locus.
Previous studies identified the binding of NF-kB to the IL-10 gene locus (42,43).
Thus, we suggest that IkB NS binding to the IL-10 gene locus is mediated by p50 and/or c-Rel, because IkB NS itself has no DNA-binding domain.
Although IL-10 appears to be directly regulated by IkB NS , IL-17A, IL-17F, and IL-22 do not contain canonical NF-kB-binding sites.
Consequently, we conclude that IkB NS does not regulate these genes directly; further experiments are needed to clarify how IkB NS regulates the expression of cytokines in an indirect manner.
Several components of the NF-kB signaling pathway are important for Th17 development.
Most upstream in the signaling complex, CARMA1 deficiency results in defective Th17 cell differentiation (44).
MALT1 is highly expressed in Th17 cells generated in vitro, and MALT1 2/2 Th17 cells produce less IL-17 and GM-CSF (45).
Loss of p65/RelA or c-Rel results in impaired Th17 induction in vitro, and c-Rel was shown to interact directly with the Rorc and Il21 promoters (46,47).
Moreover, the atypical nuclear IkB protein IkBz, another nuclear IkB protein with high sequence similarity to IkB NS , regulates Th17 proliferation in a cell-intrinsic way (48).
IkBz interacts with RORa and RORgt to regulate Th17 differentiation and Il17 gene expression (48).
Notably, CARMA1 and c-Rel are also critical for the generation of Tregs (49,50), indicating at least a partially overlapping developmental program (51).
Thus, we believe that IkB NS is a component of the common Th17/Treg NF-kB signaling cascade, because mice that are also deficient in c-Rel or CARMA1 fail to develop spontaneous autoimmunity (52,53).

In summary, our data reveal that IkB NS is necessary for murine Th17 differentiation during inflammation and infection, and it belongs to the group of NF-kBsignaling proteins that commonly regulate Treg and Th17 cell differentiation.
Hence, IkB NS exhibits diverse T cell proliferation and cytokine secretion functions and may represent a specific pharmacological target in future drug development.

While this manuscript was in revision, it was reported that IkB NS 2/2 mice are less susceptible to EAE induction, with lower Th17 frequencies in draining lymph nodes and a lack of lymphocyte infiltration in spinal cord (54).
Consistent with our data, the gene expression of IL-17A was suggested to be independent of IkB NS .
Furthermore, Heissmeyer and colleagues (55) demonstrated that Roquin and Regnase-1 inhibit IkB NS expression and, thus, impair Th17 cell differentiation.
Consistent with our results, knockdown of IkB NS in T cells under Th17-priming conditions resulted in impaired Th17 differentiation.
Taken together, IkB NS appears to be a crucial regulator of Th17 differentiation.
FIGURE 1. IkB NS deficiency results in impaired Th17 development during gut inflammation.
(A-E) Transfer colitis was induced in RAG1 2/2 mice by adoptive transfer of freshly isolated CD4 + CD25 2 T cells from IkB NS +/+ (n = 35) or IkB NS 2/2 (n = 36) mice.
Mice injected with PBS (n = 17) served as controls.
(A) The histological score is the sum of individual scores of inflammatory cell infiltration and tissue damage.
(B-E) Lymphocytes of the colon were isolated, and the expression of surface markers and intracellular cytokines was analyzed by flow cytometry.
(B) Representative dot plots.
Frequency of IL-17A + (C), IL-17A + /IFN-g + (D), and IFN-g + cells (E) within the CD4 + T cells.
(F) Transfer colitis was triggered as described above.
Where indicated, GFP + Tregs of IkB NS 2/2 Foxp3 DTR-eGFP or IkB NS +/+ Foxp3 DTR-eGFP reporter mice were cotransferred.
IFN-g + lymphocytes of the colon were analyzed by flow cytometry.
Data were pooled from two (F) or four (A-E) independent experiments.
Horizontal lines represent the mean; error bars show SEM.
*p , 0.05, **p , 0.01, ***p , 0.001, ****p , 0.0001, two-tailed Mann-Whitney U test.
FIGURE 2. Impaired Th1 and Th17 differentiation in the absence of IkB NS .
CD4 + CD25 2 CD62L + naive T cells were isolated by flow cytometry and cultured under Th1-polarizing, Th17-polarizing, or nonpolarizing (Th0) conditions.
Cells were analyzed with or without PMA/ionomycin (P/I) (A, B, E, and F) or anti-CD3/anti-CD28 stimulation (4 h) (C and D).
(A and C) The induction of IkB NS /Nfkbid mRNA was analyzed by real-time PCR.
The relative expression of Nfkbid was calculated by normalization to unstimulated T cells.
(B and D) Western blot analyses of IkB NS and b-actin protein expression.
(D) The single blot (right panel) represents the protein expression of IkB NS -deficient Th17 cells.
(E) The expression of IFN-g and IL-17A was analyzed by flow cytometry in wild-type and IkB NS 2/2 T cells upon Th1 and Th17 polarization.
Representative dot plots are shown.
(F) Statistical analysis of the frequencies of in vitro-differentiated IL-17A 2 IFN-g + (Th1) and IL-17A + IFN-g 2 (Th17) cells.
Data shown are representative of at least three (A-D) or four (F) independent experiments.
Error bars show SEM.
*p , 0.05, **p , 0.01, two-tailed Mann-Whitney U test.
FIGURE 3. IkB NS -deficient T cells display a proliferation defect during Th cell differentiation in vitro.
CD4 + CD25 2 CD62L + naive T cells were isolated by flow cytometry and cultured under Th1-polarizing, Th17-polarizing, or nonpolarizing (Th0) conditions.
Cells were analyzed after PMA/ionomycin (P/I, 4 h) stimulation.
Naive IkB NS +/+ (CD90.1 + ) and IkB NS 2/2 (CD90.2
+ ) T cells were mixed at a ratio of 1:1, labeled with CFSE, and cultured under Th1polarizing, Th17-polarizing, or nonpolarizing (Th0) conditions.
Proliferation of each genotype was analyzed by flow cytometry.
(A) Representative dot plots of viable IkB NS +/+ (CD90.1 + ) and IkB NS 2/2 (CD90.2
+ ) cells.
(B) Representative graphs of CSFE intensity of IFN-g + or IL-17A + cells (pregated to CD90.1 + or CD90.2 + cells).
(C) Statistical analysis of the division index of wild-type and IkB NS 2/2 T cells.
Error bars show the SEM of four independent experiments.
*p , 0.05, two-tailed Mann-Whitney U test.
FIGURE 4. Expression of Th17-specific cytokines is impaired by IkB NS deficiency.
CD4 + CD25 2 CD62L + naive T cells were isolated by flow cytometry and cultured under Th1-polarizing, Th17-polarizing, or nonpolarizing (Th0) conditions.
(A) T cells were stimulated with PMA/ionomycin (P/I) for 4 h or were left untreated.

Subsequently, the expression of Rorc was measured by real-time PCR, and the fold induction was calculated by normalization to UBC. (B) CFSE-labeled CD4 + CD25 2 CD62L + naive IkB NS +/+ (CD90.1 + ) and IkB NS 2/2 (CD90.2
+ ) T cells were cultured at a 1:1 ratio under Th17-polarizing conditions.
On day 4, IL-17A expression was analyzed by flow cytometry.
MFI of IL-17A for every proliferation cycle was analyzed.
Representative dot plots showing different MFI of IL-17A within five proliferation steps (G1-G5).
(C) The fold reduction in the MFI of IL-17A in IkB NS 2/2 cells compared with IkB NS +/+ cells was determined within the five proliferation steps shown in (B).
(D) Isolated naive T cells were cultured under Th17-priming conditions.
IL-17A-expressing cells were enriched via a cytokine-secretion assay.
Relative levels of cytokines in the supernatant of stimulated IkB NS +/+ and IkB NS 2/2 Th17 cells were assessed using a cytokine array membrane.
The expression of IL-2, IL-10, MIP-1a, and GM-CSF in IkB NS 2/2 cells relative to wild-type Th17 cells is shown.
(E) Supernatants were prepared as in (D), and cytokines were measured by a bead-based flow cytometry assay.
(F) Isolated naive T cells were cultured under Th17-priming conditions.
Subsequently, RNA was prepared for analyses by real-time PCR.
The fold induction of Il2, Il10, Il17a, Il17f, Il22, Ccl3, and Csf2 in Th17 cells was calculated relative to nonstimulated Th17 cells after normalization to UBC.
Error bars represent the SEM of two (D), three (A), or four (C and E) independent experiments or the mean of seven differentiations in five independent experiments (F).
*p , 0.05, **p , 0.01, two-tailed Mann-Whitney U test.
FIGURE 5. IkB NS 2/2 mice are more susceptible to C. rodentium infection.
IkB NS +/+ or IkB NS 2/2 mice were infected orally with 1 3 10 10 C. rodentium bacteria expressing the lux operon.
(A) Analysis of C. rodentium burden in stool of IkB NS +/+ (n = 14) or IkB NS 2/2 (n = 15) mice.
CFU/g of stool are plotted on a logarithmic scale.
(B) The bacterial load in IkB NS +/+ (n = 3) or IkB NS 2/2 (n = 3) mice infected with bioluminescent C. rodentium was measured in vivo by bioluminescence imaging (IVIS Spectrum CT).
Representative bioluminescence images are shown for the day of infection (day 0) and for days 5 and 10 postinfection.
(C) Statistical analyses of the total flux of bioluminescence of C. rodentium during the course of the experiment.
(D) The bacterial load in liver (IkB NS +/+ n = 6, IkB NS 2/2 n = 8) and spleen (IkB NS +/+ n = 4, IkB NS 2/2 n = 9) was analyzed 10 d postinfection.
Horizontal lines in (A), (C), and (D) represent the mean, and error bars show the SEM.
Data were pooled from at least three independent experiments with at least three mice/group (A and D) or are representative of one experiment with three mice/group (B and C).
*p , 0.05, **p , 0.01, two-tailed Mann-Whitney U test (A and D) or Student t test (C).
FIGURE 6. Fewer Th17 cells develop in IkB NS 2/2 mice upon C. rodentium infection.
A total of 1 3 10 10 bioluminescent C. rodentium bacteria was administered orally to IkB NS +/+ or IkB NS 2/2 mice.
Animals were analyzed 10 d postinfection.
(A) Cells from the colon were isolated, stained with Abs directed against CD3, CD4, IFN-g, and IL-17A, and measured by flow cytometry.
Representative dot plots are shown.
(B-D) Cells from colon, spleen, and mesenteric lymph nodes (mLN) were isolated, stained, and measured by flow cytometry as in (A).
Frequency of IL-17A + (B), IL-17A + /IFN-g + (C), and IFN-g + cells (D) within CD4 + CD3 + T cells.
(E) The relative expression of Ifng, Il10, Il17a, Il17f, and Il22 in LPLs was measured by real-time PCR and normalized to UBC. (F) Representative H&E staining of colon section.
Scale bar, 200 mm (upper panels).
The histological score was determined from colon sections of IkB NS +/+ (n = 6) or IkB NS 2/2 (n = 4) mice on day 10 postinfection (lower panel).

Data are representative of two experiments with at least three mice/group (in total IkB NS +/+ n = 9, IkB NS 2/2 n = 11 [E]) or were pooled from three independent experiments with two to four mice/group (B-D) or two independent experiments with at least two mice/group (F).
Horizontal lines represent the mean, and error bars show the SEM.
*p , 0.05, **p , 0.01, two-tailed Mann-Whitney U test.
FIGURE 7. IkB NS binds to the IL-10 gene locus in Th17 cells.
CD4 + CD25 2 CD62L + naive T cells were isolated by flow cytometry, cultured under Th17-polarizing conditions, and stimulated with PMA/ionomycin for 4 h.
ChIP was performed using an IkB NS -specific rabbit polyclonal Ab.
Representative quantitative PCR analysis of amplification of IL-10 is shown.
IkB NS 2/2 cells served as control.
The mean of two experiments is shown, error bars display the SEM.
2/2 mice, demonstrating the importance of IkB NS for the formation of Th17 cells in the inflamed gut.
Previously, we reported a reduced number of Tregs in IkB NS

row.cell: mice (17). To analyze whether the increased frequency of Th1 cells
in IkB NS -deficient animals arose from reduced numbers of Tregs, Tregs from IkB NS 2/2 Foxp3 DTR-eGFP or IkB NS +/+

p.s: We thank Sabrina Schumann for technical assistance, Alisha Bronietzki and Dr. Yvonne Neumann for critical reading of the manuscript, David Dettbarn and colleagues at the Helmholtz Centre for Infection Research (HZI) Animal Facility for excellent mouse stock breeding, and Dr. Marina Pils (HZI) and Elena Wiebe (Medical School Hannover) for help with the histology.

We are grateful to the FACS facilities, especially Dr. Lothar Groebe (HZI) and Dr. Desiree Kunkel (Berlin-Brandenburg Centre for Regenerative Therapies-Flow Cytometry Laboratory, Berlin, Germany), for help with cell sorting.
Rag1 2/2 mice were kindly provided by Dr. Thomas Blankenstein (Charite ´-Universita ¨tsmedizin Berlin).
The authors have no financial conflicts of interests.
